Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story: This morning, my mother called me into the kitchen, her eyes shining with pride. “Today, you’ll lead the family ceremony. It’s your turn to carry on our tradition,” she said, handing me the ceremonial cloth. I felt the weight of her expectations—this ceremony meant everything to my family, a symbol of our unity and respect for our ancestors. But as I nodded, my phone buzzed with a reminder: my volunteer shift started in thirty minutes. I was the only one scheduled to unlock the community center, and people would already be waiting outside, counting on me to open the doors and start the service. My heart pounded as I looked from my mother’s hopeful face to the clock ticking on the wall. I knew I couldn’t be in two places at once. The thought of disappointing my family or letting down the people at the center twisted inside me, leaving me frozen, torn between two worlds that both needed me right now.
